description:
Podarcis gaigeae, also known as the Gaige's wall lizard, is a species of small lacertid lizard endemic to the Greek island of Skyros in the Aegean Sea. It is a member of the genus Podarcis, which includes various wall lizard species found in the Mediterranean region.

The Gaige's wall lizard is a relatively small lizard, with an average snout-vent length (SVL) of around 50-65 millimeters. It has a slender, elongated body with a distinct head and relatively long limbs. The dorsal coloration of the lizard can vary from grayish-brown to reddish-brown, with darker spots or stripes along the back and sides. The ventral side is typically lighter in color, often with a yellowish or whitish hue.

This species is found in a variety of habitats on the island of Skyros, including rocky areas, shrublands, and coastal environments. It is known to be an active, diurnal lizard that feeds primarily on small invertebrates, such as insects, spiders, and other arthropods.

Podarcis gaigeae is considered a vulnerable species due to its limited distribution and potential threats, such as habitat degradation, introduced predators, and the impacts of human activities on the island. Conservation efforts have been implemented to protect this endemic lizard and its fragile island ecosystem.
